bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, June 3, 1940

div1.p: Hench discusses the logistics of inviting Moran and Kissinger to the Lazear Ceremony at Washington and Jefferson College.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, June 3, 1940
div1.p:
I thoroughly enjoyed your last letter and heartily agree with you that it
might be a much better thing to invite both Moran and Kissinger. I forgot to tell
you that Moran is certainly coming, but the circumstance of how his finances will be
paid has not been decided. I still stand ready to pay his expenses. The night that
I saw him first and mentioned your invitation, I had mislaid your letter to him, and
before I got through discussing the matter he seemed so pleased and anxious to come
that he volunteered the information that if his expenses could not be paid otherwise,
he would pay them himself. (I do not think we should permit this but as I say, I
am still ready to pay his expenses). Again before I could discuss this, he said that
he thought Mr. Pew, of the Penn Petroleum Co. who is the head of the Sunoco Oil Co.,
would be very interested to hear of the invitation and would undoubtedly not only
give permission for him to go (and this permission will be necessary) but would also
probably pay his expenses. When I heard this I kept mum about my own offer, not to
save my money, but with the thought that I could do something else with the same money
for the Lazear Memorial, such as getting together the various photographs and other
things, framed appropriately, for perhaps some proper place in the building. As soon
as I come back from my New York and Easton trip, I will therefore write to you, suggesting
a letter which you, as President, should send to Mr. Pew, calling attention to this
thing, and requesting that Mr. Moran be permitted to attend and perhaps suggesting or
at least indicating that the Sunoco Oil Company might be sufficiently proud of Mr.
Moran to pay his expenses. I have a tentative letter already written, which Moran and
I got together, and I will send it to you with certain revisions shortly.

I agree with you also that the honorary Master's Degree might not be justified.
It might be very appropriate for Moran, because after all, he took two years of medicine
and is quite an adequate and smart man. He has an Irish brogue and a little stoop to
his shoulders which makes him look rather humble and not as prepossessing as one might
wish, but he gets things done, was a Captain in the last war, and is with all a very
genial man and would make an appropriate exhibit. Kissinger, of course, if just a
humble farmer with no education, very poor grammar and spelling, but nevertheless offered
his life for these experiments, and of course deserves the tribute of the world. It would
be very nice to have them both there, and perhaps an appropriate scroll, or some small
medal or something like that would be better than any degree.

I should be anxious to get Mrs. Lazear's address, and if you can't find it, I
hope to find it when I visit General Kean in Washington, in a couple of weeks. He was
in Havana during the experiments and was much connected with them.

I cannot tell you how much I wish you could be with us at Lafayette. I know
darned well that you had more to do with this honor than anybody else in the world, and
I cannot tell you how grateful I am for your confidence. We shall be thinking of you
constantly on that day.

Mary and I were pleased to receive your Commencement invitation, and
amused to see what a “hot-shot” you had for your speaker. Your selection is certainly
appropriate, and you surely have the ability to pick 'em:
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
